content: The Act titled "Universal Higher Education and Lifetime Learning Act of 2007" consolidates education tax incentives into a higher education tax credit under Section 25A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Universal Higher Education and Lifetime Learning Act of 2007 consolidates education tax incentives into a higher education tax credit under Section 25A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The credit allows eligible students to claim 50% of higher education expenses up to $3,000 and 30% of expenses exceeding $3,000 but not exceeding $8,000 for each taxable year. The Lifetime Learning Act of 2007 limits the tax credit for higher education expenses to the individual's cost of attendance at the eligible institution. The credit allowed for any eligible student in a taxable year is capped at $12,000 minus the aggregate credit claimed in prior years. Additionally, there is a credit limitation based on modified adjusted gross income. The Lifetime Learning Act of 2007 limits the tax credit for higher education expenses based on modified adjusted gross income. The reduction in the amount taken into account for the taxable year is determined by the taxpayer's income ratio. The Lifetime Learning Act of 2007 limits the tax credit for higher education expenses based on modified adjusted gross income, which is the taxpayer's adjusted gross income increased by certain exclusions. The applicable amount varies based on filing status, with a maximum limit of $60,000 for joint returns. The tax credit for higher education expenses is limited based on modified adjusted gross income. The credit allowed for the taxable year is calculated by subtracting the regular tax liability and the tax imposed by section 55 from the sum of certain credits allowable. An eligible student is defined as an individual who meets specific requirements under the Higher Education Act of 1965. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 defines higher education expenses as costs considered in determining the cost of attendance at an eligible educational institution for the taxpayer, spouse, or dependent. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 defines an eligible educational institution as one described in section 481 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 and eligible to participate in a program under title IV of the same Act.
